author: Valerina Changarathil
title: Beach Energy boss Robert Cole resigns; consolidation likely as Cooper Basin trio now leader-less
text:
STRUGGLING oil and gas producer Beach Energy’s leading light through the oil price rout, managing director Robert Cole, has resigned for family reasons.
Mr Cole had been on leave, attending family matters in Perth, while acting chief executive Neil Gibbins managed the reins and a turnaround plan unveiled last month.
“As a result of those matters, Mr Cole has decided it is not possible to return to a full time executive role with Beach in Adelaide,” the company said today. “He has accordingly resigned.”
The former Woodside Petroleum executive vice-president replaced long-time managing director Reg Nelson in March and was charged with bringing in efficiency and change at the company at a particularly tough time in the oil industry.
Mr Cole had spoken of his aim to make the Cooper Basin oil and gas producer a top 50 ASX company in a decade through organic and inorganic growth and had been open to consolidation in the basin if it came at the right price for Beach.
Mr Cole’s resignation leaves three Cooper Basin companies without a confirmed leader with Santos managing director David Knox stepping down and Drillsearch managing director Brad Lingo quitting in July.
It is likely to reignite talks of a consolidation in the basin, especially given Kerry Stokes-led Seven Group Holdings’ 19.9 per cent stake in Beach and Drillsearch, respectively.
An EnergyQuest report released today said Cooper Basin producers have averaged a 70 per cent downturn in the value of their shares, raising the likelihood of consolidation.
Beach’s share price has fallen nearly 65 per cent since June last year and Drillsearch has slid 66 per cent.
Beach has waived the notice requirements under Mr Cole’s contract, but said he will remain with the company until October 14 to allow for an orderly transition.
Neil Gibbins will continue as interim chief executive until a new managing director is appointed.
Beach recently reported a staggering full-year loss on impairments and low oil prices - of $514.1 million, compared to last year’s profit of $101.8 million.
Yesterday it reported a minor acquisition - a 40 per cent stake in ATP 1056 in the south-eastern flank of the Cooper Basin in Queensland from AGL for $1.15 million - announced last month has fallen through.
Beach Energy shares were trading nearly three per cent lower at 50.5c at 11.45 AEST.
